sen.j: 韋那 磐鍬（いな の いわすき、生没年不明）は、日本の飛鳥時代の人物である。
sen.e: INA no Iwasuki is a person who lived in the Asuka Period, but his birth and death dates are not known.
INA no Iwasuki is a person who lived during Japan's Asuka period, but his birth and death dates are not known.
sen.cmt: 他のファイルのネイティブチェックを参考に修正しました。
sen.e: INA no Iwasuki is a person who lived during Japan's Asuka period, but his birth and death dates are not known.

sen.j: 名は石次（いわつぎ）とも書く。
sen.e: Ina's first name also spells Iwatsugi.
Ina's first name 磐鍬 also spells 石次 (Iwatsugi).
sen.cmt: 漢字表記をのこしました。
sen.e: Ina's first name 磐鍬 also spells 石次 (Iwatsugi).

sen.j: 旧仮名遣いでの読みはそれぞれ「ゐなのいはすき」、「いはつぎ」。
sen.e: commentに質問記入
sen.cmt: 旧かなづかいの「は」の訳し方不明。
sen.e: His name is pronounced "INA no Ihasuki" or "Ihatsugi" in the old Japanese kana syllabary.
His name is pronounced "INA no Ihasuki" or "Ihatsugi" in the old Japanese kana syllabary.
Ina's kabane (hereditary title) was 'Ko.'
Ina's kabane (hereditary title) was 'Ko.'
Ina's kabane (hereditary title) was 'Ko.'

sen.j: 672年の壬申の乱で大友皇子（弘文天皇）のために東国から兵力を動員する使者になったが、敵に阻まれて逃げ、任務に失敗した。
sen.e: In the Jinshin War in 672, INA no Iwasuki was chosen as a messenger to mobilize troops for Otomo no Oji (Prince Otomo, who later became Emperor Kobun) from eastern provinces, but failed to complete the mission as the enemy blocked Ina.

In the Jinshin War of 672, INA no Iwasuki was chosen as a messenger to mobilize troops for Otomo no Oji (Prince Otomo, who later became Emperor Kobun) from eastern provinces, but failed to complete the mission because he run away when the enemy blocked his way.

In the Jinshin War of 672, INA no Iwasuki was chosen as a messenger to mobilize troops for Otomo no Oji (Prince Otomo, who later became Emperor Kobun) from eastern provinces, but failed to complete the mission because he run away when the enemy blocked his way.

sen.j: 韋那氏は宣化天皇の皇子・上殖葉皇子（一説に火焔皇子）を祖とする皇別氏族で、摂津国河辺郡為奈郷に拠点を置いていた。
sen.e: Ina family was one of those branched out from the Imperial family, starting from KAMITSUUEHA no Oji (Prince Kamitsuueha, also called HONO no Oji or Prince Fire), son of Emperor Senka, and had a foothold in Ina village of Kawabe County in the Settsu Province.

Ina clan was one of those branched out from the Imperial family, starting from KAMITSUUEHA no Oji (Prince Kamitsuueha, also called HONO no Oji or Prince Fire), son of Emperor Senka, and had a foothold in Ina village of Kawabe County in the Settsu Province.
sen.cmt: 韋那氏 Ina clanとしました。
sen.e: Ina clan was one of those branched out from the Imperial family, starting from KAMITSUUEHA no Oji (Prince Kamitsuueha, also called HONO no Oji or Prince Fire), son of Emperor Senka, and had a foothold in Ina village of Kawabe County in the Settsu Province.

sen.j: 壬申の年（672年）の6月下旬に大海人皇子（天武天皇）が挙兵すると、大友皇子を戴く近江宮の朝廷は、諸方に兵を興すよう命じる使者を派遣した。
sen.e: When Oama no Miko (Emperor Tenmu) raised an army against the Imperial Court in late June, 672, the Court at Omi no miya, with Otomo no Oji as leader, dispatched messengers to the regional allies, ordering to mobilize troops.

When Prince Oama (Emperor Tenmu) raised an army against the Imperial Court in late June, 672, the Court at Omi no miya, with Prince Otomo as leader, dispatched messengers to the regional allies, ordering to mobilize troops.
sen.cmt: ここでは皇子をPrinceで統一します。
sen.e: When Prince Oama (Emperor Tenmu) raised an army against the Imperial Court in late June, 672, the Court at Omi no miya, with Prince Otomo as leader, dispatched messengers to the regional allies, ordering to mobilize troops.

sen.j: 東国には韋那磐鍬、書薬、忍坂大摩侶が遣わされた。
sen.e: To the eastern regional allies, INA no Iwasuki, FUMI no Kusuri, and OSHISAKA no Omaro were sent.
To the eastern regional allies, INA no Iwasuki, FUMI no Kusuri, and OSHISAKA no Omaro were sent.
To the eastern regional allies, INA no Iwasuki, FUMI no Kusuri, and OSHISAKA no Omaro were sent.

sen.j: 使者の通過点にあたる美濃国は大海人皇子がまっさきに押さえたところで、近江国との境にある不破関はその兵力で封鎖されていた。
sen.e: However, the Province of Mino, which the messengers had to pass through, was the first region controlled by Oama no Miko.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the Province of Mino, which the messengers had to pass through, was the first region seized by Prince Oama, and his troops closed Fuwa-no-seki checking station located on the border with the Province of Omi.

However, the Province of Mino, which the messengers had to pass through, was the first region seized by Prince Oama, and his troops closed Fuwa-no-seki checking station located on the border with the Province of Omi.

sen.j: 磐鍬は、6月26日夜に不破に近づいたとき、山中に敵兵が潜んでいるのではないかと考えて、一行から独りだけ遅れて進んだ。
sen.e: When the messengers came closer to the Fuwa-no-seki checking station, Iwasuki thought that enemy soldiers may be hiding in the mountain, and proceeded alone, keeping a distance behind the others.

When the messengers came closer to the Fuwa-no-seki checking station on the night of June 26, Iwasuki thought that enemy soldiers may be hiding in the mountain, and proceeded alone, keeping a distance behind the others.

When the messengers came closer to the Fuwa-no-seki checking station on the night of June 26, Iwasuki thought that enemy soldiers may be hiding in the mountain, and proceeded alone, keeping a distance behind the others.

sen.j: はたして伏兵があって、書薬らの後ろを遮断した。
sen.e: As Iwasuki expected, they were ambushed, and interrupted between Iwasuki and others.
As Iwasuki expected, they were ambushed and interrupted between Iwasuki and others.
sen.cmt: カンマを削除しました。
sen.e: As Iwasuki expected, they were ambushed and interrupted between Iwasuki and others.

sen.j: 磐鍬はこれを見て逃げかえり、書薬と忍坂大摩侶は捕らえられた。
sen.e: After witnessing the ambush, Iwasuki ran away while FUMI no Kusuri and OSHISAKA no Omaro were caught.
After witnessing the ambush, Iwasuki ran away while FUMI no Kusuri and OSHISAKA no Omaro were caught.
After witnessing the ambush, Iwasuki ran away while FUMI no Kusuri and OSHISAKA no Omaro were caught.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』の上記の箇所に、『釈日本紀』は調淡海や安斗智徳の日記を典拠に注記して、「石次は兵が起こるのを見て逃げかえった」と記す。
sen.e: Adding to the descriptions above which appears in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), "Shaku Nihongi," an annotated text of the Nihon Shoki, also says, "Iwatsugi fled as soldiers of the enemy camp rose," citing diaries of TSUKI no Oumi and ATO no Chitoko.

Adding to the descriptions above which appears in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), "Shaku Nihongi," an annotated text of the Nihon Shoki, also says, "Iwatsugi fled as soldiers of the enemy camp rose," citing diaries of TSUKI no Oumi and ATO no Chitoko.

Adding to the descriptions above which appears in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), "Shaku Nihongi," an annotated text of the Nihon Shoki, also says, "Iwatsugi fled as soldiers of the enemy camp rose," citing diaries of TSUKI no Oumi and ATO no Chitoko.

sen.j: 磐鍬が石次とも書かれたことがわかる。
sen.e: The article in "Shaku Nihongi" shows that Iwasuki's name was also written Iwatsugi, with different characters.
The article in "Shaku Nihongi" shows that Iwasuki's name was also written Iwatsugi, with different kanji characters.
The article in "Shaku Nihongi" shows that Iwasuki's name was also written Iwatsugi, with different kanji characters.
